image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

items.synopsis: Optus says it is aware of an issue impacting mobile and internet customers, with services down since early this morning across the country.

title.children: Optus reports national outage affecting millions of customers

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell celebrates hitting the winning runs for Australia against Afghanistan at the Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell — hampered with a bad back and crippling cramps — hits a stunning double century to guide Australia to victory over Afghanistan.

title.children: 'The greatest ODI innings ever': Hobbled Maxwell hits record double-ton in Aussie World Cup win

image.altText: snorkellers holding placards underwater.

items.synopsis: Ocean scientists say fossil fuel use needs to stop if ecosystems such as the Great Barrier Reef are to have a fighting chance of survival.

title.children: Scientists' clarion call on fossil fuel projects as oceans warm faster than predicted

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu in front of an Israeli flag

items.synopsis: For months Israel has been on the brink of a civil war, spurred by the government's plans to drastically change parts of Israeli life and society. And at the heart of it has been one man — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, writes Allyson Horn.

title.children: 'The real problem is the guy who's our leader': Israelis are furious with PM Benjamin Netanyahu

image.altText: A wide shot of a land with soldiers and tanks among destroyed buildings with a ferris wheel in the distance and ocean beyond.

items.synopsis: Israel says its forces are operating deep in Gaza City, adding that Hamas' most senior leader in the enclave is isolated in his bunker. Follow live.

title.children: IDF troops move into 'the very heart of Gaza' as Israel marks one month since Hamas attacks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel, which is trying to clear out Gaza City, said it gave residents a window from 10am to 2pm local time to leave for the southern part of the Gaza Strip. Residents say Israeli tanks have been moving mostly at night with Israeli forces largely relying on air and artillery strikes to clear a path for their ground advance. Gaza's interior ministry says 900,000 Palestinians are still sheltering in northern Gaza including Gaza City. "The most dangerous trip in my life. We saw the tanks from point blank (range). We saw decomposed body parts. We saw death," resident Adam Fayez Zeyara posted with a selfie of himself on the road out of Gaza City. While Israel's military operation is focused on the northern half of Gaza, the south has also come under attack. Palestinian health officials said at least 23 people were killed in two separate Israeli air strikes early on Tuesday in the southern Gaza cities of Khan Younis and Rafah. More than 10,000 people, around 40 percent of them children, have been killed since fighting began according to counts by health officials there. "We are civilians," said Ahmed Ayesh, who was rescued from the rubble of a house in Khan Younis where health officials said 11 people had been killed. "This is the bravery of the so-called Israel — they show their might and power against civilians, babies inside, kids inside, and elderly." UN Human Rights Commissioner Volker Turk said it "has been one full month of carnage, of incessant suffering, bloodshed, destruction, outrage and despair."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 900,000 Palestinians still in northern Gaza, interior ministry says

children.content: Israel, which is trying to clear out Gaza City, said it gave residents a window from 10am to 2pm local time to leave for the southern part of the Gaza Strip.
Residents say Israeli tanks have been moving mostly at night with Israeli forces largely relying on air and artillery strikes to clear a path for their ground advance.
Gaza's interior ministry says 900,000 Palestinians are still sheltering in northern Gaza including Gaza City.

props.alt: sozens of people carrying bags walking through a wide open street with trees and buildings on either side

children.content: Palestinian civilians evacuating from the north of the Gaza Strip walks towards south.
(Reuters: Ahmed Zakot)

"The most dangerous trip in my life. We saw the tanks from point blank (range). We saw decomposed body parts. We saw death," resident Adam Fayez Zeyara posted with a selfie of himself on the road out of Gaza City.
While Israel's military operation is focused on the northern half of Gaza, the south has also come under attack.
Palestinian health officials said at least 23 people were killed in two separate Israeli air strikes early on Tuesday in the southern Gaza cities of Khan Younis and Rafah.
More than 10,000 people, around 40 percent of them children, have been killed since fighting began according to counts by health officials there.
"We are civilians," said Ahmed Ayesh, who was rescued from the rubble of a house in Khan Younis where health officials said 11 people had been killed.
"This is the bravery of the so-called Israel — they show their might and power against civilians, babies inside, kids inside, and elderly."
UN Human Rights Commissioner Volker Turk said it "has been one full month of carnage, of incessant suffering, bloodshed, destruction, outrage and despair."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's Defence Minister Yoav Gallant says soldiers are now operating in the heart of Gaza City. "IDF forces…came from the north and the south. They stormed it in full coordination between land, air and sea forces," he said. "They are manoeuvring on foot, armoured vehicles and tanks, along with military engineers from all directions and they have one target — Hamas terrorists in Gaza, their infrastructure, their commanders, bunkers, communications rooms. "They are tightening the noose around Gaza City." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also made the announcement in a televised statement. "Gaza City is encircled, we are operating inside it," he said. "We are increasing pressure on Hamas every hour, every day. "So far, we have killed thousands of terrorists, above ground and below ground." Mr Gallant said Hamas' most senior leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar, was isolated in his bunker.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel now operating in 'heart of Gaza City'

children.content: Israel's Defence Minister Yoav Gallant says soldiers are now operating in the heart of Gaza City.
"IDF forces…came from the north and the south. They stormed it in full coordination between land, air and sea forces," he said.

"They are manoeuvring on foot, armoured vehicles and tanks, along with military engineers from all directions and they have one target — Hamas terrorists in Gaza, their infrastructure, their commanders, bunkers, communications rooms.
"They are tightening the noose around Gaza City."

props.alt: A wide shot of a land with soldiers and tanks among destroyed buildings with a ferris wheel in the distance and ocean beyond.

children.content: Israeli soldiers on the ground in Gaza
(Israel Defense Forces via Reuters)
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also made the announcement in a televised statement.
"Gaza City is encircled, we are operating inside it," he said.
"We are increasing pressure on Hamas every hour, every day.
"So far, we have killed thousands of terrorists, above ground and below ground."
Mr Gallant said Hamas' most senior leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar, was isolated in his bunker.

image.altText: A teddy bear surrounded by floral tributes left in a park

items.synopsis: Police have interviewed the driver at the centre of a tragic crash that killed five people in the regional Victorian town of Daylesford, but no charges have been laid.

title.children: Driver in Daylesford pub crash interviewed by police as investigation continues

image.altText: a skyline with houses

items.synopsis: There's nothing in the RBA governor's statement to suggest she is thinking of pushing up rates again, and financial markets are also betting this rate hike will be the last, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Australia is the odd one out on interest rates around the world

image.altText: a woman holding a dog and sitting at a table reading a pile of papers

items.synopsis: Retirees and aged pensioners have to choose between leaving cities they have lived in for decades or becoming homeless amid a worsening rental crisis.

title.children: Spike in seniors seeking public housing, homelessness services after being priced out of rental market

image.altText: A smiling family of five stand around a table with cakes on it.

items.synopsis: Lisa Mammone and her husband do all they can for their kids, but they are bracing to make even more sacrifices as interest rates hit a 12-year high.

title.children: The Mammones live from one payday to the next. The RBA rate rise will mean saying 'no' to their kids more

image.altText: Palestinians look for survivors following an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis refugee camp.

items.synopsis: War began on October 7 when Hamas militants crossed from Gaza and killed 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians, and abducted more than 200. Since then, Israel has bombarded the Hamas-run strip, killing more than 10,000 people, around 40 per cent of them children, according to regional health officials.

title.children: Israel's war with Hamas enters its second month

image.altText: Clare leans against a window in her bedroom.

items.synopsis: Clare is autistic and was struggling to fit in at school, but when life went online in the pandemic, things improved. Experts say she's not alone.

title.children: Clare used to worry she was 'too much'. When school went online, things got better

image.altText: An artwork showing a photo of a bird on the right and an image of what people thought was a bunyip on the left.

items.synopsis: Almost 150 years ago, three miners headed into a swamp for an evening of wild duck hunting. They discovered a terrifying creature with a roar "like that of a lion" in the darkness.

title.children: Why conservationists are working to protect the creature behind Hexham bunyip folklore

image.altText: An Indigenous lady wipes away tears from her face with a tissue

items.synopsis: The mother of teenager Cleveland Dodd, who became WA's first youth to die in custody, expresses disappointment with Corrective Services Minister Paul Papalia over revelations uncovered by the ABC about what happened the night he was found unconscious in his cell.

title.children: 'He told a big lie': Cleveland Dodd's mother accuses WA Corrective Services Minister of dishonesty over his death in custody

image.altText: Front of a car crashed into a tree

items.synopsis: The 27-year-old man was charged with nine offences after the fatal crash on Monday.

title.children: Allegedly unlicensed driver charged over Sydney car crash that killed two boys

image.altText: A man wearing a cap and work clothes stands on the inside of cattle yards behind a large wooden fence.

items.synopsis: Memories of Black Summer remain strong for many in this South East Queensland region, where heavy fuel loads and parched conditions have locals preparing for the worst.

title.children: 'Chaotic summer ahead': residents fear dry spell could bring bushfires roaring back to Scenic Rim

image.altText: A woman in a peach coloured hospital gown holds three white pills in her left hand

items.synopsis: Antibiotics have been around for less than a century. But as resistant bacteria become increasingly difficult to treat, we risk a greater number of deaths from infections.

title.children: What would a world without life-saving antibiotics look like?

image.altText: Georgina Ker looks pensive as she hugs her 15-year-old daughter.

items.synopsis: With her son missing weeks of school at a time, Georgina Ker followed the "tough love" prescription she was told would remedy her son's "behaviour problem". A new survey has found more than one-in-three parents have reported school refusal with their children in the past year.

title.children: First data on school refusal trend suggests 'shocking' problem is much bigger than first thought

image.altText: People holding up phones and taking photos of Albanese.

items.synopsis: The Chinese media's coverage of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's visit to China this week has generally been positive, with experts saying it reflects Beijing's changing approach to the relationship.

title.children: China's media had criticised Australia for years. So how has it covered the prime minister's long-awaited visit?

image.altText: A storm cloud building over trees and paddocks

items.synopsis: Some of the storm activity has the potential to become severe, carrying the risk of gusty winds, heavy rain and hail.

title.children: After the driest September-October on record, much of Australia to cop severe thunderstorm activity

image.altText: Sign in red dirt reading Arnhem Space Centre.

items.synopsis: The fledgling Arnhem Space Centre in the remote Northern Territory is looking to substantially expand its facilities and launch capacity if it's given the tick of approval.

title.children: One launch a week, 14 launch pads: Massive expansion pegged for remote Australian rocket base

image.altText: Venus appears as a yellowed marble, cracks run across its face

items.synopsis: Researchers have made the first direct detection of atomic oxygen in the atmosphere of Venus. Some say it builds the case the planet was more hospitable in the past.

title.children: Oxygen detection in Venus' atmosphere points to a very different past

image.altText: Two silver towers are engulfed in flames and smoke, with a bridge in the foreground

items.synopsis: The Hamas-led attack on October 7 was the latest in a long line of historic intelligence failures.

title.children: 'Talk about irony and insanity': How some of history's biggest intelligence failures have led to disaster

image.altText: A composite image of two women in black face veils

items.synopsis: When the Pakistani government abruptly announced all foreigners illegally living in the country had to leave, hundreds of thousands of Afghans packed up and headed to the border. But these two women decided to stay, fearing they would be worse off if they returned to their homeland.

title.children: If Paavaana is forced out of Pakistan, she fears her abusive ex will go straight to a Taliban court to force her to remarry

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Australian Antarctic Division were left scrambling after a decision to block RSV Nuyina from transiting the Tasman Bridge and refuelling close to port, with the true cost of a 660km detour now revealed.

title.children: A bridge too far for banned icebreaker — and new documents reveal just how much it will cost taxpayers

image.altText: Michelle Bullock speaks at a podium with branding behind her. She is gesturing with her hand.

items.synopsis: Interest rates hit a 12-year high as the Reserve Bank resumes hiking, with a 0.25 percentage point rise taking the cash rate to 4.35 per cent.

title.children: The RBA has raised interest rates, despite 'the economy showing more signs that it is weakening'

image.altText: Silhouette of man and child with southern lights

items.synopsis: An aurora australis visible to the naked eye has been seen across Western Australia in the brightest display of southern lights in years.

title.children: Aurora australis 'brighter than in Antarctica' seen across WA

image.altText: A view from a high building shows a large, snowed-in basketball arena below, minus its roof.

items.synopsis: It is the second fatal gym collapse in the Chinese province in just a few months, after 11 people were killed when a school gym was destroyed in July.

title.children: Basketball gym collapses in China's Heilongjiang province, killing three and injuring one

image.altText: Anthony Albanese shakes hands with Xi Jinping in front of the Australian and Chiense flags in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is wrapping up in China after a whirlwind three-day trip aimed at stabilising ties between the two countries. From an invite to Australia to symbolism and plenty of talk about friendship, these are the key takeaways from the visit.

title.children: 'A handsome boy from Australia' and an invite for the president: The key takeaways from Albanese's China visit

image.altText: Top view of a glass of orange juice.

items.synopsis: Questions are being raised about the system for prescribing "takeaway" methadone following the tragic death of a six-year-old in New South Wales, who drank orange juice mixed with the opioid replacement medication.

title.children: Boy died after drinking orange juice mixed with mother's 'takeaway' methadone, inquest hears

image.altText: people in masks perform on top of a snow covered building, right image is a selfie of person in delivery driver uniform

items.synopsis: Just hours after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Lucy Shtein knew it was time to escape. If she ever returns, a Moscow court says, she faces immediate arrest.

title.children: Pussy Riot member Lucy Shtein fled Russia dressed as a delivery driver — she's now on an international wanted list

image.altText: King Charles sits in crown and royal regalia on a throne

items.synopsis: The new monarch sets out the UK government's plans to tackle crime, boost growth and water down climate change measures.

title.children: Charles III delivers first King's Speech in 72 years
